English (United States)(en-US): And then he went like this, didn’t he?
Put his head.
Against the wall.
Thump. Thump. Thump.
(What’s that splating sound?\nI keep hearing it.)
Oh.
I’m feeling dizzy.
I need a hole to throw up in.
But faint abandonment creeps in.
Head against the wall…
like this.
Red? I don’t have the faintest idea\nwhat to do. Not a single clue. Not one.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 레드? 정말 어쩌면 좋을지 하나도\n모르겠어. 하나도. 하나도.

English (United States)(en-US): That which explodes like a flare.\nHas been spilt. Smashed and crushed.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 섬광탄처럼 터지는 것. 엎질러진\n것. 박살이 나 우그러진 것.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m feeling dizzy.
Did your human feel this way too?
Did he throw himself out of the way of the\nswelling clock needle but end up impaled on it?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 비대해지는 시계 바늘을 피하기 위해 몸을\n던졌지만 도리어 쿡 찢어지고 말았던 걸까?

English (United States)(en-US): It hurts. And yet how strange.
Why do I find comfort in pain?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나는 왜 고통에서 안락을 찾은 거지?

English (United States)(en-US): Why must I be like this?
Why?
The thing about letters is, it’s good\nto have someone close by read them.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 편지란 건 말이야. 가까이에 읽어 줄\n이가 있으면 좋다고 생각해.

English (United States)(en-US): How very foolish of me to think of you\nonly now—you visit me every day.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 왜 이제야 떠올린 걸까?\n매일 내 창가에 들르는 너를.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m writing this letter\nwhile staring up at you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 지금 널 보며 편지를 쓰고 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): Where I began, perhaps where\nI’ll never revisit... My Moon.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나의 시초지이자, 어쩌면 이제\n영영 돌아가지 못할... 나의 달.

English (United States)(en-US): You seem unusually pale tonight.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오늘 밤의 너는 유독\n희게 질린 것 같아.

English (United States)(en-US): I wonder if the surrounding darkness\nis finally creeping into your light.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 테두리를 둘러싼 어둠이 기어이\n네게 침범하려 하는 걸까.

English (United States)(en-US): <nickname> says that Earth is\nquite a distance away from you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내 인간 친구가 말해 주길, 지구는\n너와 꽤 멀리 떨어져 있대.

English (United States)(en-US): Apparently, light from here takes\none-point-three seconds to get to you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이곳의 빛이 네게 출발해도\n일 점 삼 초가 걸린다고 했어.

English (United States)(en-US): One. point. three. seconds!
Four thousand stars would be born and\nthirty more would implode, with time to spare.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 사천 개의 새 별이 탄생하고, 삼십 개의\n별이 폭발하고도 남는 시간이지.

English (United States)(en-US): Still, no need to be too sad.
Once I’m no longer a dream, once\nI become a light-like substance,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내가 꿈을 지나고, 빛과\n비슷한 속성의 존재가 되면...

English (United States)(en-US): I’ll be with you faster\nthan the speed of light.
So you won’t be lonely up there.
Til we meet again.
Oh, <nickname>. Will you look at\nthis baby bird atop my head?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오, <nickname>. 내 정수리를 밟고\n서 있는 아기새를 봐 줄 수 있어?

English (United States)(en-US): See, what happened was......
The clouds were\ndrifting idly away.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 구름이 권태롭게 뒷짐을 지고 흘러가고 있었어.

English (United States)(en-US): I followed the treacherous route up the cliff\nfor a closer look, nearly losing an arm!
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 난 깎아지르는 벼랑을 등반해,\n기필코 그에 닿아 보리라 결심했지!

English (United States)(en-US): So... you made it up on the\nwindowsill to look at the sky, <nickname>?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 어... 그러니까 창문 위에 어렵게\n올라가서 하늘을 봤다고, 뭉치야?

English (United States)(en-US): Eh... That’s one way to put it.
And then this bird landed on me,\nlike she had been expecting me.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이 새는 기다렸다는 것처럼 나에게 내려앉았어.

English (United States)(en-US): It happened when the shadow of\nthat desk covered the floor in half,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그게 저 책상의 그림자가 방바닥을\n반틈 가리고 있을 때의 일인데,

English (United States)(en-US): and now darkness has set\nand she still hasn’t budged.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 완전히 어둠이 내려앉은\n지금도 떠나질 못하고 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): It pains me to say it, but...
I think this bird is trapped in my clingy\nswamp of a body, robbed of the blue sky.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 푸늘 하늘의 자유를 포획당한 채, 내 끈끈한\n늪 같은 몸뚱이에 붙잡혀 버린 게 아닐까.

English (United States)(en-US): Death is coming for her, inch by inch. And it\nwill start with her legs twisting and rotting.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 앞닥칠 죽음을 기다리며. 천천히, 천천히,\n다리부터 뒤틀리다 썩어 가지 않을까.

English (United States)(en-US): But <nickname>, she doesn’t deserve this\nkind of pain. It will be a bleak tragedy.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그치만, <nickname>, 그건 이 아이가 겪어선\n안 될 고통이야. 시커먼 비극이야.

English (United States)(en-US): Please, <nickname>.\nYou have to save her!
But are we sure she’s trapped?’
But doesn’t her chirping sound joyful, <nickname>?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그런 것치곤 맑은 소리로\n지저귀지 않아, 뭉치야?

English (United States)(en-US): No. This is her neck-deep in the filthy\nmud, barely breathing through her beak,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아니, 얘는 나의 진흙탕 속에 가라앉으며\n손바닥 하나만 겨우 내밀고 있어.

English (United States)(en-US): frantically crying out for help. Begging\nme to please, please let her go.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 간절히 도움을 청하고 있는\n거야. 제발, 제발 놓아 달라고.

English (United States)(en-US): But it can’t be.\nThis bird is singing.
...... with her beak\ntwitching in delight!
Is that really true, <nickname>?
...... Really? Really?
Yes, trust me.
What a mistake! I couldn’t\nsee myself in the window.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 오해했어! 유리창에는 내\n모습이 비치지 않는단 말야.

English (United States)(en-US): Well, her feet do seem\nto be sinking bit by bit,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 뭐, 뭉치 말대로 발이 조금씩\n빠지는 것 같긴 하지만,

English (United States)(en-US): but it looks like she’s flapping\nher wings and having fun.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 날갯짓하며 놀고 있는 걸로\n보여. 즐겁다는 몸짓이야.

English (United States)(en-US): Well... Well!
So she was singing for me?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그러니까 이게 원래는 나를\n위한 음악이었단 말이지?

English (United States)(en-US): How beautiful.
A voice like the finest of\nfeathers woven together.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 깃털로 빚은 소리가 있다면 이런 느낌일까.

English (United States)(en-US): Baby bird! It turns out\nI’m safe enough for you.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 아기 새야! 내가 너에겐 덜 위험한 존재였나 봐.

English (United States)(en-US): I think this marks the start\nof a beautiful friendship.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 다행이다. 아름다운 우정의 시작일 수 있겠어.

English (United States)(en-US): but make sure to scrub your\nfeet in the river afterwards, alright?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 그래도 나중에, 꼭 강가에 가서\n발을 깨끗이 닦아 줘야 해? 알았지?

English (United States)(en-US): Promise me.\nPromise me you will.
<nickname>.
The saying ‘If you think\nit’s okay, it’ll be okay,’
I think I’m successfully proving it.
Well, I think so.\nHow do I seem to you?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나는 그렇게 생각하는데\n너는 내가 어때 보여?

English (United States)(en-US): Especially bright.|A little precarious.
What?
Are you sugarcoating your words?
Why?
Am I hard to look at?
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이런 날 보고 있기 힘들어서 하는 말이야?

English (United States)(en-US): It’s not that...
It’s okay.
The world that I see with\nmy chalk-drawn eyes
only has to paint\nmy bit of the canvas.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 내 몫의 도화지만 꾸며 주면 그만.

English (United States)(en-US): I’m glad. It really felt like\nI had a lucky coin then.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 나는 기꺼워. 그땐 정말 행운의\n동전이라도 가진 기분이었어.

English (United States)(en-US): So that’s how I feel now.
I can’t take care of a traveler\nflapping her wings on my own.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 날갯짓하는 나그네는 나의\n힘으로는 돌볼 수 없고

English (United States)(en-US): I make one-sided, indefinite\nplans to meet with the Moon.
In the end, I’m a black canvas\nthat can’t be painted on.
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 결국 난 칠할 수 없는 검은 도화지라는 걸

English (United States)(en-US): And though I’m realizing this all\nover again for the eighty-seventh time,
Korean (South Korea)(ko-KR): 이제 여든일곱 번째 정도\n새롭게 깨닫게 되어도

English (United States)(en-US): It’s okay. It’ll be okay.
It’s okay. It’s only temporary.
It’s okay. It’s what I wanted.
That’s all.
